dublin_core.dcvalue: OBJECTIVE To determine the effectiveness of personal digital assistant devices on achievement of memory and organization goals in patients with poor memory after acquired brain injury DESIGN Assessor blinded randomized controlled trial SETTING Specialist brain injury rehabilitation hospital inpatients and outpatients PARTICIPANTS Adults with acquired brain impairments 85 traumatic brain injury aged 17 years who were assessed as having functional memory impairment on the Rivermead Behavioural Memory Test General Memory Index INTERVENTIONS Training and support to use a personal digital assistant for eight weeks to compensate for memory failures by an occupational therapist The control intervention was standard rehabilitation including use of non electronic memory aids MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Goal Attainment Scale which assessed achievement of participants daily memory functioning goals and caregiver perception of memory functioning and General Frequency of Forgetting subscale of the Memory Functioning Questionnaire administered at baseline pre randomization and post intervention eight weeks later RESULTS Forty two participants with memory impairment were recruited Use of a personal digital assistant led to greater achievement of functional memory goals mean difference 1 6 95 confidence interval CI 1 0 to 2 2 P 0 0001 and improvement on the General Frequency of Forgetting subscale mean difference 12 5 95 CI 2 0 to 22 9 P 0 021 CONCLUSIONS Occupational therapy training in the use of a handheld computer improved patients daily memory function more than standard rehabilitation
A randomized controlled trial of the effectiveness of handheld computers for improving everyday memory functioning in patients with memory impairments after acquired brain injury.
